Situation1: This is the last weekend before the partner relocates abroad for months.
Expectation2: Represent clients in court hearings and trials
Situation2: A contested motion is scheduled soon, and the client relies on effective advocacy to preserve their position.
Story: I stare at my phone, reading the text from my partner: “Can’t believe it’s our last weekend together before I leave. Let’s make it special?” My heart aches. I want nothing more than to hold her hand, laugh over coffee, and memorize every detail of her face before she boards that plane. But my laptop pings with another email—my client’s case, the one I’ve been building for weeks, is set for a crucial hearing on Saturday. The judge won’t reschedule, and my client’s future hinges on my arguments. I feel the weight of both worlds pressing down on me. My partner expects my undivided attention, to feel cherished before months apart. My client expects unwavering commitment, to trust that I’ll fight for them when it matters most. I pace the room, torn between love and duty, knowing that no matter what I choose, someone I care about will be let down.
